The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The poor soldier: a comic opera. In two acts. With all the original songs. Written by John O'Keefe, Esq; ... As acted at the Theatre-Royal, Covent Garden.
titleStmt.author: O'Keeffe, John, 1747-1833.

editionStmt.edition: A new edition, improved, and carefully corrected.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original from the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE POOR SOLDIER, A COMIC OPERA.
IN TWO ACTS. WITH ALL THE ORIGINAL SONGS.
WRITTEN BY JOHN O'KEEFE, Eſq AUTHOR of the SON-IN-LAW, AGREEABLE SURPRISE, CASTLE OF ANDALUSIA, And other Dramatic Pieces.
AS ACTED AT THE Theatre-Royal, Covent Garden.
A NEW EDITION, IMPROVED, and carefully CORRECTED.
DUBLIN: Printed by M. DOYLE, No. 6, Abbey-Street.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: FOR ſhame, Darby—Stay where you are—I hate to have any one by when I'm talking to my ſweetheart.

sp.speaker: Darby.
sp.p: Now I always like to be by when I'm talking to my ſweetheart.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Oh, that I was ſo unfortunate as to think her a pretty girl!

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul now, ſhe is grown very uncivil, for ſhe turns up her noſe at me.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: I know one ſhe will have—the old ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Is ſome old Frenchman to take the girl from poor Darby! (Weeps.)—I never dream but of poor Kathleen—But here we are under the window—Father Luke threatened poor Pat, that if he came to his ward, Norah, he would put him into the biſhop's court, and therefore, Pat, full of grief and vexation, went for a ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Holeo! Kathleen—ſhe little dreams that her Dermot's under the window.

lg.l: Sleep on, ſleep on, my Kathleen dear,
May peace poſſeſs thy breaſt;
Yet doſt thou dream thy true love's here,
Depriv'd of peace and reſt?

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The birds ſing ſweet, the morning breaks,
Thoſe joys are none to me;
Tho' ſleep is fled, poor Dermot wakes,
To none, but love and thee!

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: That ſinging would not wake an owl out of her ſleep.—I'll try.

lg.l: Dear Kathleen, you, no doubt,
Find ſleep how very ſweet 'tis;
Dogs bark, and cocks have crow'd out,
You never dream how late 'tis.
This morning gay,
I poſt away,
To have with you a bit of play.
On two legs rid,
Along to bid
Good morrow to your night cap.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Laſt night a little bowzy,
With whiſkey, ale, and cyder,
I aſk'd young Betty Blowſey,
To let me ſit beſide her.
Her anger roſe,
And ſour as ſloes,
The little gypſy cock'd her noſe:
Yet here I've rid,
Along to bid
God morrow to your night cap.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Who is that?—Dermot?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Yes I am—Darby. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Stay I'll come down.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Oh, I knew I ſhould bring her down—I am a fine markſman.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: So you muſt come ſinging at my window, but I tell you once for all, I won't have you—as I hope for man I won't.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: That's a good joke!—hope for man, and not have me.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I'll tell you.

lg.l: Since love is the plan,
I'll love if I can,
But firſt let me tell you what ſort of a man:
In addreſs how compleat,
And in dreſs, ſpruce and neat,
No mater how tall, ſo he's over five feet:
Not dull, nor too witty,
His eyes I'll think pretty,
If ſparkling with pleaſure wherever we meet.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Tho' gentle he be,
His man he ſhall ſee,
Yet never be conquer'd by any but me.
In a ſong bear a bob,
In a glaſs a hob nob,
Yet drink of his reaſon his noddle ne'er rob.
This is my fancy,
If ſuch a man can ſee,
I'm his if he's mine; until then I am free.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Have I not every thing comfortable about me? —A ſnug farm, heifers, and ſheep, and a pad to ride on to chapel on Sunday, and a potatoe garden to walk in on a week day—only look at me—I am as right a fellow as you have ever ſeen.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Don't think of talking to me.—Do you know that I am an heireſs?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: You are a tight little heifer.—I believe your father, old Jorum, who kept the alehouſe, left you well enough in the world, as a body may ſay.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Left me well enough indeed!—Did he not leave me a great ſum of money, a matter of 11l. half a barrel of ale untapped, half a dozen plates, a three-legged ſtool, and a bald filly to ride on?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Now ſhe is got upon her bald filly, the devil himſelf would not take her down.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Now I am an heireſs, a huſband I'll have, this night, if I can.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Out of my ſight, or I'll box your ears.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I'll fit you for your jibes and jeers.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I'll cock my cap at a ſmart young man.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Another I'll wed this day, if I can.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: No Kate, I'm your humble bee,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Go dance your dogs with a fiddle dee dee. For a ſprightly lad is the man for me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You'll ne'er meet ſuch a kind ſoul as me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Like ſweet milk turn'd, to me now ſeems love.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: The fragrant roſe does a nettle prove.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Sour curds I taſte, tho' ſweet milk I chuſe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: And with a flow'r I ſting my noſe.

div.head: SCENE II. A Country Houſe and Wood.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Here's the houſe that contains my charming Norah, I ſhall ſoon rouſe them, I warrant.

lg.l: The twins of Latona, ſo kind to my boon,
Ariſe to partake of the chaſe;
And Sol lends a ray to chaſte Dian's fair moon,
And a ſmile to the ſmiles of her face.
For the ſport I delight in, the bright queen of love
With myrtles my brows ſhall adorn;
While Pan breaks his chaunter, and ſkulks in the grove,
Excell'd by the ſound of the horn.
The dogs are uncoupled, and ſweet is their cry,
Yet ſweeter the notes of ſweet echo's reply:
Hark forward, my honies, the game is in view,
But love is the game that I wiſh to purſue.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The ſtag from his chamber of woodbine peeps out,
His ſentence he hears in the gale;
Yet flies, till, entangled in fears and in doubt,
His courage and conſtancy fail.
Surrounded by foes, he prepares for the fray,
Deſpair taking place of his fear;
With antlers erected, a while ſtands at bay,
Then ſurrenders his life with a tear.
The dogs are uncoupled, &c.
The meadows look chearful, the birds ſweetly ſing,
So gaily they carol the praiſes of ſpring;
Tho' nature rejoices, poor Norah ſhall mourn,
Until her dear Patrick again ſhall return.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Ye laſſes of Dublin, ah, hide your gay charms,
Nor lure her dear Patrick from Norah's fond arms;
Tho' ſattins, and ribbons, and laces are fine,
They hide not a heart with ſuch feelings as mine.

sp.speaker: Norah.
sp.p: As I live that's the gentleman my guardian is always teazing me about.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: My charming Norah, let us haſte from this place,—and our cares ſhall be few.

sp.speaker: Norah.
sp.p: I cannot ſtay.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Perhaps my Norah will take a walk with me.—See the garden is yonder—The fine morning with you is charming, but appears to me nothing without you.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: For you, deareſt maiden, the pride of the village,
The town and its pleaſures I freely reſign;
Delights ſpring from labour, and ſcience from tillage,
Where love, peace, and innocence ſweetly combine:
Soft tender affection, what bliſs in poſſeſſing!
How bleſt when 'tis love that inſures us a bleſſing!
Careſs;'d; ah, what rapture in mutual careſſing,
What joy can I wiſh for, was Norah but mine!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The feaſts of gay faſhion with ſplendor invite us,
Where luxury, pride, and her follies attend;
The banquet of reaſon alone ſhould delight us,
How ſweet the enjoyment when ſhar'd with a friend!
Be thou that dear friend, then, my comfort, my pleaſure,
A look is my ſun-ſhine, a ſmile is my treaſure.
Thy lips, if conſenting, give joy beyond meaſure,
A rapture ſo perfect, what joy can tranſcend!

sp.speaker: Norah.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, permit me to withdraw, as our villagers are very cenforious, and our being ſeen together will neither add to your honour, or my reputation.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: Monſieur—Monſieur!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: I came to tell you—bleſs my ſoul, I run ſo faſt—I came to tell you—I am out of breath—it is all blown.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What's blown?—My love affair I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: De Mareſchall Powder is all blown out of de vindow.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then you muſt ſend to town for more.

sp.speaker: Bagat.
sp.p: I think I do very well, in the very village where I was born the people take me for a Frenchman, though I do not know one word of French.—Here lives my old ſweetheart Norah! O my dear Norah!

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Once more returned to my native village after two long years abſence.—Up to the heart in love, and not a ſix-pence in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Odds zounds—I am glad to ſee you—What my ſoldier returned?—How are you, my old friend?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I thank you, I am bravely.—How fares it?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Purely—except one thing—a cow ſtrayed from me laſt week.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: How does my dear Norah?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: She is very well.—How came you to liſt for a ſoldier?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: When her uncle would not give his approbation to my marriage with Norah, and I could not have her without his conſent, I lifted for a ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Well, and how do you like being a ſoldier?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: A ſoldier is the fineſt life in the world.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Then how happy you live.

lg.l: How happy the Soldier who lives on his pay,
And ſpends half a crown out of ſix-pence a day!
Yet fears neither juſtices, warrants, or bums,
But pays all his debts with the roll of his drums.
With a row de-dow, &c.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: He cares not a marvedy how the world goes,
The King finds him quarters, and money and clothes:
He laughs at all ſorrow, whenever it comes,
And rattles away with the roll of the drums.
With a row-de dow, &c.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: The drum is his glory, his joy and delight;
It leads him to pleaſure, as well as to fight.
No girl when ſhe hears it, tho' ever ſo glum,
But packs up her tatters, and follows the drum.
With a row-de-dow, &c.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: We will have all the neighbours here to day. A ſoldier's is a happy life.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Will you be a ſoldier?—then come with me, and I will introduce you to the ſerjeant.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Ecod, with all my heart, I think I ſhould look very well in regimentals.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Let me ſee how this hat will become you.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: What cut is that on your forehead?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Only a wound I got in battle in endeavouring to ſave my captain's life—I was left for dead in the field of battle, bleeding in my country's cauſe—there was glory for you.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: So they found you bleeding in your glory—here take your hat—I don't think regimentals would become me at all.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Nothing, only it's ſo conceited for a man to wear a black patch. Good bye, Pat.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Where are you going? This is the way to the ſerjeant's.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: No, no, this is the way to my ſerjeant's—the devil row-de-dow me if you get me to be a ſoldier.
Now for my charming Norah! and then for a pitcher of friendſhip with all my acquaintances.

lg.l: The wealthy fool with gold in ſtore,
Will ſtill deſire to grow richer;
Give me but health, I aſk no more,
My little girl, my friend and pitcher.
My friend ſo rare, &c.
Tho' fortune ever ſhuns my door,
(I know not what can thus bewitch her)
With all my heart: can I be poor,
With my ſweet girl, my friend and pitcher?
My friend, &c.

div.head: SCENE, Inſide of Father Luke's Houſe.

sp.p: MADEMOISELLE Norah, open de door if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Norah.
sp.p: (from within) Begone about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: My dear Norah, give me une petite kiſs.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: (without.) Where is my ſweet girl, my Norah?

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: O be gar, here be ſomebody coming, what ſhall me do! Begar me go hide myſelf in dis cloſet. (Runs to hide.)

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: (from within.) Begone about your buſineſs; deſire you will leave the houſe directly.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: What is this I hear; ſure I know that voice — A pretty compliment after two years abſence!

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Is it you, my deareſt Pat?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Sweet Norah, if I was ever dear to you.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: If I was ever dear to you, how could you leave me then?—but judge of me by theſe tears.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: My charming girl, what tears are theſe?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: They are tears of joy at your return.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: Ah pauvre Bagatelle!

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I think I hear a noiſe.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: If it ſhould be my uncle, what will become of me? for he's more averſe to our union than ever.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I'll ſlip into the cloſet.

div.stage: [Pat goes to the cloſet. Bagatelle comes out.]

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: How you do, Sir? me hope you very well.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: (to Norah.) Are theſe your ſighs for my abſence, and tears of joy at my return, to be lock'd up with a raſcally hair-dreſſer.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: Raſcal—hair dreſſer,—You ſhall give me ſatisfaction—You ſhall meet me with—

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: What, with your curling irons—away with you, or I will beat you while I can hold a ſplinter of Shillelah, or do you chuſe to walk out of the window?

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: Sir, to oblige you, I will walk out of the window—but I had much rather walk down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Begone.— [Exit Bagatelle.] Ah! my dear Norah, could I think you would be ſo unkind to me?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Could you think me falſe?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: If I did, my heart is my own, however.

sp.speaker: PAT.
sp.l: A roſe tree in full bearing,
Had ſweet flowers fair to ſee;
Tho' eager then to win it,
I find a canker in it,
And now throw it far away.

sp.speaker: NOR.
sp.l: So late I lov'd you dearly,
Tho' loſt now each fond delight.
The clouds ſeem big with ſhowers,
Sunny beams no more are ſeen;
Your falſehood has chang'd the ſcene.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: Monſieur Darby — Monſieur Darby?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: I believe that's Monſieur Bag and Tail.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: I am glad I find you, Darby,—I was hunting you all over the village, and could not find you.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: That's becauſe I am ſo wrapt up in love.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: You muſt know I am going to kill Pat the ſoldier, and you muſt be my friend.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Had not you better kill Dermet, and then I'd be your friend?

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: Oh, but Pat the ſoldier has affront me—you ſhall be my ſecond.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Your ſecond!—could not you make me your third or fourth?

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: (Shewing a letter.) By gar, this be de lettre de moi.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Oh, what, you'll leather him more!

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: C'eſt une autre choſe.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: What, I muſt get two other ſhoes!

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: C'eſt un barbare.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: What, becauſe you're a barber!

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: Oh!—this is de lettre Lord Lofty's coachman did write for me—You read, Darby.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Let me ſee—"This comes hopping"—Oh, I'll run all the way if that's all—This comes hopping you're in good health, as I am at this preſent writing:—Tho' you think yourſelf a great officer, you ſhall not make me walk out of the window. I will have Norah in ſpite of you. Meet me at the Elm Groves at ſeven o'clock to give me ſatisfaction; but not with curling irons. I am your's, as in duty bound.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: You ſee I will not ſign my name, becauſe I do avoid the law. You muſt carry it for me.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: I'll take care Pat ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: Well, now I have ſettled this affair d'honneur, I will go—bruſh my maſter's coat.

Since Pat is turned ſoldier, I will not give it him, for as he wanted Monſieur Bag and Tail to walk out of de window, he may perhaps want me to walk up the chimney—the boy at the public houſe ſhall give it him.—Oh! my Kathleen, you have made me fall in love, it would have been well for me if I had fallen into the river.

div.head: SONG.
div.opener: [Tune, There was a School Miſtreſs in Limerick.]

lg.l: Tho' late I was ſnug, plump, and jolly,
I now am as thin as a rod;
Oh! I'm afraid this ſame melancholy,
Will ſoon leave me under the ſod.
Dootherum, doodle-adgity, nadgety, tragedy, rum,
Gooſeterum, foodle-igity, fidgety, nidgety, mum.
Oh! Kathleen, why would you flout me,
A boy that is cozey and warm;
Has every thing decent about me,
My ſnug little cabbin and farm.
Dootherum, &c.
What tho' I have not ſav'd much money,
No duns in my chamber attend;
A Sunday I ride on my pony,
And ſtill have a bit for a friend.
Dootherum, &c.
The cock courts his hens all around me,
The ſparrow, the pigeon, and dove;
Oh! how all this courtſhip confounds me,
For want of the girl that I love!
Dootherum, &c.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I find more danger in encountering the eyes of my charming girl, than in a battle; and can you prefer your poor ſoldier to all mankind?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: You are only a common ſoldier in the army, but to me you are a field officer in my heart.

div.head: AIR XI.
div.l: Farewell, ye groves, and chryſtal fountains,
The gladſome plains, and ſilent dell;
Ye humble vales, and lofty mountains,
And welcome now a lonely cell.
And ah, farewell, fond youth, moſt dear!
Thy tender plaint, the vow ſincere,
We'll meet and ſhare the parting tear,
And take a long and laſt farewell.

lg.l: Tho' Leixlip is proud of its cloſe ſhady bow'rs,
Its clear falling waters, and murm'ring caſcades;
Its groves of ſweet myrtle, its beds of ſweet flow'rs,
Its lads ſo well dreſs'd, and its neat pretty maids.
As each his own village muſt ſtill make the moſt of,
In praiſe of dear Carton, I hope I'm not wrong;
Dear Carton, containing what kingdoms may boaſt of,
'Tis Norah, dear Norah, the theme of my ſong,

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Be gentlemen fine, with their ſpurs and nice boots on,
Their horſes to ſtart on the Curragh of Kildare;
Or dance at the ball, with their Sunday new ſuits on,
Lac'd waiſtcoats, white gloves, and their nice powder'd hair.
Poor Pat, while ſo bleſt in his mean humble ſtation,
For gold, or for acres, he never ſhall long;
One ſweet ſmile can give him the wealth of a nation,
From Norah, dear Norah, the theme of my ſong.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What! do I ſee my laſs in company with a common ſoldier?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: You will be ſure to come at the time you promiſed.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I will—moſt happy am I!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Good morrow, brother ſoldier—A good handſome girl that?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: She is thought ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You ſeem to be well with her.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, but I fear I ſhall ſoon loſe her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You have a rival then, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now for a picture of myſelf. [Aſide.] Some rich raſcal, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I envy him not his riches—and as to your other epithet, I am ſure he does not deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Becauſe he is an officer, and therefore a man of honour.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It is a pity you was not an officer! You have been in the ſervice?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Yes, I have ſeen ſome ſervice. I was wounded at the battle of Johnſon's Ford, in America, in ſaving my captain's life.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: (As I live, the very man who ſaved my life in that engagement.) [aſide.] I hope that you got your reward?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I looked for none; I did no more than my duty in fighting for my country, and in defending my captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I am going from her I love; becauſe fortune prevents our union.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Take my advice,—go and ſee her once more.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Sir, you ſeem a good-natur'd gentleman, I will venture to ſee her again, ſince you adviſe me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What a noble ſpirit! Let the embroider'd epaulet diſtinguiſh the officer: Let him take a leſſon from this man. There is more merit to be found, perhaps, under this worſted lace, than under gold or ſilver taſſels.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Are you the man in the red coat?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, my boy, I believe I am the man in the red coat; what's your buſineſs with me?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Darby deſir'd me to give you this.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Darby.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let's ſee? reads. This comes, hopping you are in good health as I am at preſent. You think yourſelf a great officer; but you ſhall not make me walk out of the window again. I will have Norah in ſpite of you. Meet me at the Elm Groves, at ſeven o'clock, to give me ſatisfaction; but not with curling irons. I am your's, as in duty bound.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This Norah ſeems to have a number of admirers. And ſo, my little hero—heyday, the herald is off—Seven o'clock—Smyth, go and ſee what ſort of ſtuff this challenger is made of.

div.head: SCENE III. Outſide of Dermot's Houſe.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Well, now, Dermot, I'm come to your houſe with you—what is this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Derm.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Aye do; ſpeak freely—unburden your conſcience the ſame as if—Have you tapp'd that barrel of ale yet?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Indeed I have, and you ſhall taſte it.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Aye, he wanted to come round me now about my ward Kathleen; a wheedling ſon of a—

div.stage: Enter Dermot from the Houſe, with a Jug of Ale.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: My dear child, what's that?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Your favourite brown jug, ſir.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: (after drinking.) Now, child, why will you do theſe things?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: I'll prime him well before I ſpeak about Kathleen; 'tis a hard heart that a drop o' drink won't ſoften.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: This jug and I have been old acquaintance, Dermot.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: You may ſay that, Sir.—

lg.l: Dear Sir, this brown jug, that now foams with mildale,
Out of which I now drink to ſweet Kate of the vale,
Was once Toby Philpot, a thirſty old ſoul,
As e'er crack'd a bottle, or fathom'd a bowl.
In boozing about, 'twas his praiſe to excel,
And among jolly topers he bore off the bell.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: It chanc'd in dog-days, as he ſat at his eaſe,
In his flow'r-woven arbour, ſo gay as you pleaſe.
With a friend and a pipe puffing ſorrow away,
And with honeſt old ſtingo was ſoaking his clay,
His breath doors of life on a ſudden were ſhut,
And he died full as big as a Dorcheſter butt.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: His body, when long in the ground it had lain,
And time, into clay, had diſſolv'd it again;
A Potter found out in its covert ſo ſnug,
And with part of fat Toby he form'd this brown jug,
Now ſacred to friendſhip, and mirth, and mild ale;
So here's to my lovely ſweet Kate of the vale.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: How do you do, Father Luke?

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Go away, Darby, you're a rogue.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Will you conſent that I ſhall marry Kathleen?

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Is it you? you reprobate!

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Do, and I'll give your reverence a ſheep.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Oh, well, I always thought you were a boy that wou'd come to ſome good—a ſheep!—you ſhall have Kathleen — but you have been very wicked.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: What, an't I your prieſt, and know what wickedneſs is? but repent it and marry.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: I will marry and repent it.

lg.l: You know I'm your prieſt, and your conſcience is mine;
But if you grow wicked, it's not a good ſign;
So leave off your raking, and marry a wife;
And then, my dear Darby, you're ſettled for life.
Sing Ballynamony, Oro,
A good merry wedding for me.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The bans being publiſh'd, to chapel we go,
The bride and bridegroom in coats white as ſnow;
So modeſt her air, and ſo ſheepiſh you look,
You out with your ring, and I pull out my book.
Sing, &c.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: I thumb out the place, and I then read away,
She bluſhes at love, and ſhe whiſpers, obey.
You take her dear hand to have and to hold,
I ſhut up my book, and I pocket your gold.
Sing, &c.
The ſnug little guinea for me.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Is Dermot within Sir?

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Don't think of him, child.—To her man, now, and put your beſt leg foremoſt. (apart to Darby.)

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: I don't know which is my beſt leg.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Arrah go.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: (kiſſes her.) Oh how ſweet her lips are! ſpeak for me, Father Luke.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Hem! Kathleen, child!— (apart to Darby.) Is the ſheep fat?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: As fat as bacon, Sir.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Child! this boy will make you a good huſband—now won't you, Darby?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Oh, the devil a better.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I'll have no huſband but Dermot. (ſings.)

lg.l: Dermot prattles pretty chat,
Darby gapes like any oven,
Dermot's neat from ſhoe to hat,
Darby's but a dirty ſloven.
Lout, Looby,
Silly Booby,
Come no more to me a courting.
Oh, was my dear,
My Dermot here,
With all his love and gay ſporting.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Dermot's teeth are white as egg,
Lips as ſweet as ſugar candy;
Then he has ſuch a handſome leg,
Darby's is knocker-kneed and bandy.
Lout, Looby, &c.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Dermot walks a comely pace,
Darby, like an aſs, goes ſtumping;
Dermot dances with ſuch grace,
Darby's dancing's only jumping.
Lout, Looby, &c.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: I tell you, child, Dermot is an ugly man and a bad chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Dermot, you are a bad man and an ugly Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Here, you Dermot.—Take your jug again; you empty fellow! I am going to marry Kathleen, and you muſt give her away, Sir.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Faith, I muſt have her firſt; and I came now for your conſent.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Eh!—what!—you marry her!—No ſuch thing—put it out of your head, and don't make a Judy of yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Oh, if that's the caſe, the two fat ſheep I intended to make you a preſent of, I'll drive to the fair to-morrow, and get drunk with the money.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Hay!—Two ſheep!—come back here, Dermot; 'tis a great ſin to get drunk, Sir—Darby, if you have nothing to do, get about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Dermot, child!—Is it not this evening that I am to marry you to Kathleen?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis me you are to marry to her.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: You! you ordinary fellow!

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Yes—and I am to give you—

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: (to Dermot.) Two ſheep, is it!

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; two fine ſheep.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Darby, you don't marry Kathleen.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: No! arrah, why ſo?

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Bekeys 'tis two to one againſt you—ſo get away, Darby.

sp.speaker: Kath. and Der.
sp.p: Aye, aye, get away, Darby.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Children, I expect Captain Fitzroy at my houſe about my niece Norah, and I'll couple you all as ſoon as I get my thumb upon matrimony.

sp.speaker: DARBY.
sp.l: To the church I'll hand her,
Then thro' the world I'll wander;

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I wonder who this challenger can be; who comes here? I will ſtep aſide and watch.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Ah! Bag and Tail if I fall will you take my corpſe (not a very ugly one) to Dermot's wedding—I will ſtand behind you thus. (Putting Bagatelle in a parallel line before him) I might as well ſtand behind a pitch fork.—I had rather ſtand behind a Dutch weaver than a French church-warden.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: Zounds! here is my maſter!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did you ſend a challenge to me, you raſcal?

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: It was Lord Lofty's coachman wrote it.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: I went to Father Luke's houſe—and there I got the letter—and ſo I went to Father Luke's houſe, and the letter was given to me—now I have it—and this is all I know about it. I did not go to ſchool for nothing.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Get you gone. [Exit Bagatelle.] You had better ſtick to your ſpade than meddle with ſword and piſtol.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Hollo! Captain!

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I would wiſh to know whether you think me or Dermot the prettieſt boy for it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Puppy!

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Puppy!—You a Captain indeed!—Hollo, corporal!

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: I find I muſt go up to town to learn to ſpeak to this captain.

div.head: DARBY.—AIR XVIII.
div.opener: [Tune, I'll have a Wife of my own.]

lg.l: Since Kathleen has prov'd ſo untrue,
Poor Darby! ah, what can you do?
No longer I'll ſtay here a clown,
But ſell off, and gallop to town;
I'll dreſs, and I'll ſtrut with an air,
The barber ſhall frizzle my hair.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: In town I ſhall cut a great daſh;
But how for to compaſs the caſh!
At gaming, perhaps, I may win;
With cards I may take the flats in,
Or trundle falſe dice, and they're nick'd:
If found out, I ſhall only be kick'd.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: But firſt for to get a great name,
A duel eſtabliſh my fame;
To my man then a challenge I'll write;
But firſt, I'll be ſure he won't fight.
We'll ſwear not to part till we fall,
Then ſhoot without powder, and the devil a ball.

div.head: SCENE, Father Luke's Houſe.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: If you do not conſent to marry Captain Fitzroy, the man of my choice, I will ſend you to France, and put you in a convent.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: I am well content. I never will marry the man that I do not approve of.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: You are content! You put me in a paſſion,—and then you are content! Go, get you gone into that room, and there ſtay until you go to France, Mrs. Knapſack.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who is this that you are going to ſend to France?

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: My ward, Sir, who won't conſent to marry you. She is robunxious.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Will you reſign her to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: With that key I deliver up my authority; and now if I find Mr. Patrick, her lover, I will ſend him to the county jail for a vagabond.—A jade! to loſe the opportunity of making herſelf a lady.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Here comes the ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I came as I promiſed.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Was you ever brought to the halberts?— How came you abſent from your regiment?—Have you a furlough?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: No, Sir, not about me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have the honour to bear his majeſty's commiſſion; and I will have you taken up for a deſerter, for the good of the ſervice. I have a perſon here ready to take you into cuſtody.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: What a cruel piece of treachery!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: [Goes into Norah's room, and having brought her out, ſays] Dear Norah, ſince you have refuſed my hand, will you permit me to reward your conſtancy, by putting you into the hands of your lover?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: I'm all amazement, my Patrick!

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Let us kneel and thank our deliverer.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: To keep you no longer in ſuſpence, know then that I am that officer whoſe life you ſaved at Johnſon's Ferry at Carolina, in America; I have a commiſſion to beſtow, (Produces a commiſſion.) which I now deſire, gallant youth, you will take from me as a reward for your honour, bravery and generoſity.— I wanted to find you out.—Here, heaven bleſs you both. (Joining Pat and Norah's Hands.)

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I could ſcarcely think you would remember your poor Soldier—but my gratitude is too great for utterance.

div.stage: Enter Father LUKE, DARBY, DERMOT, and KATHLEEN.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Oh! here he is, Darby, lay hold of him.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Not I—I am no conſtable.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Then the ſerjeant ſhall lay hold of him.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: O, don't you ſee the white ſerjeant has hold of him already?

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: What brings you with that fellow •

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, Sir, don't abuſe the man you'll ſhortly make your nephew.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: Me bring a foot ſoldier into my family!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He's no longer ſo, Sir, I having a commiſſion to diſpoſe of, have given it to him.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: An officer! Oh! that alters the caſe entirely.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Pat an officer!—Upon my ſoul, I'll liſt tomorrow morning in ſpight of the black patch.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Dear Norah, I wiſh you joy.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, and don't make ſo free with a captain's lady.

sp.speaker: F. Luke.
sp.p: But captain, why do you give up my niece?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Becauſe Sir, I have found ſuch ſuperior merit in this POOR SOLDIER.

sp.speaker: FITZROY.
sp.l: What true felicity I ſhall find,

sp.speaker: NORAH.
sp.l: No future ſorrows can grieve us,
If you will pleaſe to forgive us;

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.l: With my commiſſion, yet deareſt life,
In love, your poor ſoldier you'll find me!

sp.speaker: KATHLEEN.
sp.l: Thus Love my wiſhes has granted,
I get the dear lad that I wanted;
To my own little Dermot has join'd me.

sp.speaker: DARBY.
sp.l: You impudent huſſey, a pretty rake!
Has got a nice—kick in her gallop.

sp.speaker: Father LUKE.
sp.l: In marriage I'll ſoon tie you all up.

sp.speaker: DERMOT.
sp.l: The devil a bit one cares a bean,
And there we'll be coupled for ever.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.l: The laurel I've won in the field, Sirs,
Yet now, in a garden, I yield, Sirs;
Your mercy's my ſword and my ſhield, Sirs;
